Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Quantifying the Reactive Surface Area of Enviromental Solids
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports the research of Professors Peggy A. O'Day from the University of California- Merced, Karl T. Mueller from Pennsylvania State University and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, and James D. Kubicki of Pennsylvania State University who will perform collaborative research that will investigate reactive surfaces of environmental solids and their dynamic nature. Competitive adsorption, kinetics, and aging in aqueous systems of divalent cations sorbed to oxide and clay mineral surfaces will be examined through the development of novel, site-specific probe molecule(s) using solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy in conjunction with complementary spectroscopic/microscopic characterizations and computational chemistry. This research will address fundamental, long-standing questions about active, molecular binding sites at surfaces of environmental solids and their dynamic nature.

Accurate scaling of mineral surface reactivity is broadly applicable and essential to a number of important applications of societal relevance. Potential broader impacts include, for example, assessing risks associated with environmental contaminants such as surface and subsurface migration or natural attenuation of metal, radionuclide, and organic contaminants; quantifying processes such as nutrient input of P, N, and Fe sorbed on mineral particles into lakes or the oceans; and estimating the extent of CO2 reaction and sequestration by minerals in subsurface injection. This research program will train graduate students and postdoctoral scholars in interdisciplinary chemical environmental sciences involving multiple and iterative spectroscopic characterization methods and quantitative computational approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed long-standing questions about active, molecular binding sites at environmental surfaces and their dynamic nature by combining spectroscopic characterizations (synchrotron X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR)) with advanced computational chemistry (density functional theory (DFT), molecular dynamics (MD), and theoretical X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) calculations). We examined sorption of Cd, a toxic heavy metal, to two common soil minerals, kaolinite (Al2Si2O5(OH)4) and gibbsite (Al(OH3)).

Intellectual Merit: Results showed that experimental X-ray absorption features were in qualitative agreement with DFT/MD minimizations of periodic atomic models showing energetic differences among different Cd bonding configurations that could be attributed to different populations of surface complexes on each mineral surface. Solid-state NMR of probe molecules was used to determine structural information about specific nuclei and their surrounding environments, aiding the determination of quantities of binding sites for metal sorption and the chemical form(s) of the species bound to the surfaces. The combination of experimental and theoretical results suggest that gibbsite surfaces stabilize direct bonding of Cd to surface oxygen atoms (inner-sphere complexes) at low surface coverages, and combinations of mononuclear and multinuclear complexes or nanoparticles at high coverages. On kaolinite, mononuclear inner- and outer-sphere complexes appear to be stable after aging rather than multinuclear phases. Increasing aqueous Cl– concentration in sorption experiments and CdCl2 solutions showed that the presence of a Cl ligand shifts electron density from Cd to hybridized Cl 3d orbitals overlapping with Cd 4p states, consistent with DFT calculations and NMR chemical shifts for aqueous model species and solid Cd phases.

Broader Impacts: The combination of experimental, spectroscopic, and computational methods is significantly advancing our ability to describe and predict the chemical behavior of important environmental species in solids, in aqueous solutions, and at mineral surfaces. Molecular-scale knowledge of reactive surface sites and surface complex speciation contributes directly to quantitative geochemical models that provide important constraints to larger-scale simulations of environmental mobility and cycling of chemical constituents. This project contributed to the interdisciplinary education and training (fully or partially) in chemical sciences of two post-doctoral scholars (one female), four Ph.D. graduate students (one female), two MS theses (both female students), and three undergraduate students, two as part of UC Merced's Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI) Scholars Program.
